WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone know any good sources on the empowering potential of humour in activism?
WRITING.TEXT: This is a little bit out there but I am conducting some research around gender and sexuality for my dissertation and one of things that has come up a lot with my participants is how they use humour to make light of everyday experiences of sexism and homophobia. They are in no way diminishing how shitty these experiences are but rather ridiculing the absurdity of the way their oppressors thing in a way that subverts and reclaims power (I guess?). Anyway, because there are so many great well read activists on this page, I wanted to ask if anyone knew of any good sources that look at the power of humour in such circumstances. I did try Google but I ended up with a lot of shittystuff on how sexist and homophobic humour is good and not offensive, which is obviously a far cry away from what I'm looking for . Edit: just to give an example, one scenario was making fun of how gay the queer pride and all male straight pride parade was and another was joking about homophobes doing homophobia badly by showing me a really ridiculous comment that was supposed to be offensive but missed the mark

WRITING.TITLE: Can anyone recommend any literature that challenges reductive biological understandings of gender and sexuality, specifically understandings that rest on differences in brain structure?
WRITING.TEXT: I recently read a study that claimed trans people had the brain of the opposite sex, a similar claim that has been made about gay people in the past. Someone responding to article challenged the idea of a male versus female brain for not only ignoring a great deal of overlap between the brains of different genders but also failing to account for how observed physiological differences could be the product rather than cause of the social organisation of gender I.e. in a world less demarcated by gender or with a different organisation gender, such brain structures would look different. I'm already familiar with critiques around intersex so ut is this last part I'm most interested in reading more about. If anyone knows any could literature that focuses on how biological differences are actually created by norms, attitudes and behaviours, i'd love to hear about it.

WRITING.TITLE: Can anyone recommend any good literature that explores how online activism, particularly LGBTQIA+ online activism, has enabled new possibilities for organising and resisting offline?
WRITING.TEXT: Just to provide a bit of background info, over recent years, I have noticed a strong queer resistance to the commercialisation of LGBTQIA+ culture. Though the commercial gay scene/pride events have long been criticised for privileging white gay cis men, it is only in the last few years (in the UK at least) that I #8217;ve seen serious offline resistance to commercial gay culture. There have been lots of protests at mainstream pride events for being trans-exclusionary/whitewashing queer history, and there seems to be a resurgence of a much more politicised scene aimed at providing spaces for groups within the LGBTQIA+ community who have long been excluded/forgotten. Anyway, I #8217;m interested in knowing if anyone has come across any good literature that a) explores the recent emergence of this much more radical intersectional queer culture *offline* and b) considers the internet #8217;s role in facilitating this. There is lots of literature on how the internet has afforded LGBTQIA+ people with new opportunities for identity work, community building and activism *online* but I #8217;m interested in literature that goes further in considering how such possibilities online have enabled some of the changes I #8217;ve witnessed offline.

WRITING.TITLE: A story about successfully challenging transphobia (as a cis person). I #8217;m not sure if this is the right place to share this but I thought I #8217;d share because it seemed to work.
WRITING.TEXT: Before I start, I just want to say that I understand that what I #8217;m about to describe might be very difficult for a trans person if confronted with a transphobe but it could potentially be a useful technique for allies? Anyway, here goes. I was recently at a queer/ feminist conference having an interesting conversation with someone about how sexuality is fluid. To my surprise, this person went on to say how she didn #8217;t agree with trans women because she felt they were assimilating with a type of femininity that feminism has been trying resist. You know the score. Anyway, I was quite tired and socially anxious so I didn #8217;t start arguing with her (as I usually would). Instead, I just started talking about a few trans people I know that challenged her perspective. I spoke about how my one trans friend, who I #8217;ll call Adele, had issues with some trans women bullying her for not conforming to hyperfemininity and passing when she came out. I told her how this friend strongly identified with women who were caring and empathetic, like her mum and grandmother who were both teachers and activists, and that she rejected what she has has described as catty competitive femininity. Immediately this woman started talking about her own experience of feeling like she had to live up to certain types of femininity because of cis girls in school. I told her my friend described these women as the mean girls of the trans community, which she could really identify with. After that, i just said trans women, like cis women, express femininity in a range of ways, sometimes they hurt other women by expecting they live up to certain standards of femininity, but so do cis women. I said that if we want to critique that, shouldn #8217;t we just talk about shitty women behaving that way In general? To my surprise, she actually agreed. After that, we started talking about expressions of femininity in general. I mentioned that if she had an issue with trans women being hyperfeminine even if they were not pushing such femininity on to other women, that was different, but I asked her how trans women wearing say make-up or revealing clothing is any different from the many cis women that do the same? She couldn #8217;t answer. I didn #8217;t get into the whole discussion around how more normative expressions of femininity are not oppressive because I felt it would deflect from my aim for the conversation, which was to get her to see that regardless of where she stands on such issues of gender expression, trans women, like cis women, express themselves in lots of different ways and shouldn #8217;t be singled out. Again, if she has an issue with women wearing makeup, why single trans women out when cis women also wear make up. She seemed to buy it. I also mentioned that none of the trans women I know live up to the kind of femininity often presented by trans women like Caitlyn Jenner in the media (not that such expressions of femininity are bad thing, her politics aside of course) . I asked her if she had met many trans women, which surprise surprise she hadn #8217;t. I suggested that maybe her idea of trans women was limited by limited media representations. I asked her to imagine what I would think of cis women if the only cis women I #8217;d met were from magazines and TV. She got the picture. Anyway, sorry for waffling on. I just wanting to share this story because it was first time I actually felt like I got through to someone being so outwardly transphobic. I #8217;m attributing it to being non-confrontational, which has not been my usually method when handling bigots of any variety. *However *, I understand that this isn #8217;t always possible, nor should it have to be when facing confrontation! This isn #8217;t some attempt to tone police but for rather to share an encounter that actually seemed to get through a lot of the ignorance and misinformation that surrounding this woman #8217;s opinions of trans women.

WRITING.TITLE: How is easy is it for people living in countries in countries with internet censorship to overcome institutional barriers?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi everyone, I'm writing a social science paper on the democratising (albeit limited) effect of digital media and communication. I've nodded to the fact that such potential is limited by digital censorship in various countries such as Iran, Belarus and China. However, this got me thinking about whether, or perhaps a better question would be to what extent, people in such countries overcome such institutional barriers through the likes of VPNs? Would ordinary people in say China have the skill to overcome such institutional barriers, and if so, does anyone have any idea how common it is for citizens to bypass such limitations. WRITING.TITLE: What do people think about gender differences in retirement ages?
WRITING.TEXT: I was talking to a friend from The Czech Reblic Recently, and she told me that during communism, women were able to retire several years earlier (I think 5 years) for every child they had because women were required to work and often ended up taking on the majority of childcare. While heavily gendered and problematic, this got me thinking that perhaps that is one of the reasons women we're able to retire earlier elsewhere? And if it wasn't, shouldn't women taking on such extra work be granted earlier retirement? Here in the UK, there has recently been a big increase to women's retirement age, which has hit a a lot of women who had children and worked at times when men did nothing at home. And then of course there are all the women that still take on most/all domestic roles in addition to working full time. For that reason, I many women should be able to retire earlier, or at least, primary care givers who have also worked,i.e. mostly women, should.

WRITING.TITLE: What do people on this page think about free speech?
WRITING.TEXT: I know this is not strictly feminist but it obviously has implications for feminist politics and activism. I'm not talking about platforming or no-platforming but rather state censorship. A part of me would love nothing more than for the state to *completely* stop the spread of misinformation but I'm a) sceptical of the idea that state will ever have our best interests at heart when it comes to defining what is misinformation and b) worried that this will set a precident for censorship against marginalised groups in the future. Edit: I'm not someone who feels there needs to be less regulation than there already is. In fact, as a European, i would argue that some countries need more regulation. I think the definition of free speech in the US is particularly toxic and quite frankly, in the case of broadcasters like Fox News operating, not so democratic . However, i do have concerns with how governments may abuse such power against marginalised groups in the future. Im a feminist but wanted to ask this question to other feminists because in the past, I've seen other feminist on this group express some really interesting perspectives on the topic.

WRITING.TEXT: A few people on Facebook are labelling this misogynistic but I know lots of women who are also not into having sex during periods. I am sure that for a lot of people this is very specifically about period blood but given how many people are queasy around blood in general, I'm sure many would object to any kind of sex where blood was present. I've noticed that some people try to rationalalise such aversions with comments like 'how many guys objecting to this are into anal', rightfully exposing the irrationality around concerns around hygiene, which i totally agree with. However sexuality is not always so rational (and im not sure it ever will be). People don't always fully understand why they like/dont like various things, particularly when it comes to sex. If we were to start to get people to think rationally about this stuff and engage in sexual practices accordingly, there wouldn't be much grounds for people to be grossed out by the likes of feet and watersports when engaging in say rimming because the latter is no more hygeinic. It strikes me that a common denominator in what grosses people out in sex is anything connected with unfamiliar odour, which triggers feelings of uncleanliness *even* for a great many things that are more clean than many other things they engage with. Again, it's irrational but im not sure its always something a person change. I'd be interested in people's thoughts. https://www.facebook.com/10513336322/posts/10158393868391323/ Edit: i just wanted to make it clear that im not defending anyone who says period sex is disgusting because such statements are not only often hypocritical, as many saying such things engage in lots of things that are less clean than blood. However, this doesn't mean they have to be into it

I could have had an argument with him about how I think life doesn't begin at conception but I didn't because I kind of felt that doing so might be counter productive, *but* I'm happy to be challenged on this, especially given that his opinion was not without implications. I mean, there isn't really a democratic mandate, and i say this as someone who would never support LD. The leave campaign was found guilty of being in breach of electoral law. Had they overspent as they did in a general election or legally binding referendum, there would have been grounds for the Supreme Court to *enforce* another election/2nd referendum. However, because the UK only has advisory referendums, the court couldn't invalidate the result because the result was never sovereign. As a result, we have ended up with an advisory referendum being used to push for something that would not have been allowed from a legally binding one. This is far from democratic. That said, i agree that the position on the EU is complex and that there are good reasons for wanting to leave. However, i think the leftists that voted brexit are idealists. For being rude to customers, when in fact she was just being typically Czech like her male colleague. He was seen as professional, whereas she was seen as a b*****. No it's not rude. Not everything means the same outside of your culture. As I mentioned, In Czech it is considered rude to be overly friendly. Service can come across cold because of *cultural differences* but it isn't as if the workers there are shouting or getting angry with customer; their expression is just fairly neutral and direct but that can come across as rude to people from different cultures. If they started providing American style customer service, many locals would find it strange, fake or even rude because it is considered overly familiar and unprofessional (the opposite). However, as mentioned, western tourists often give Czech men a break because their formal and distant manner is more likely to be read as professional. To a Czech person, it is normal whether from a man or woman. There is no gendered expectation in this regard. I am not Czech but I lived there for a few years. When I first moved there I did think people were cold and therefore rude but once I got to know the culture, I realised it was just different. People are quite distant and formal with strangers *but* when you get to know people, that changes. The thing I loved most about this was that at no point did I ever experience anyone being friendly unless they meant it because until someone gets to know/like you, the relationship is distant by default. There was something really honest about this. Nobody pretending to like anyone they couldn't possibly know they like. As another northern male, i find this discussion quite interesting because of intersections of class. The word love (or duck depending on location) are very much ingrained in class in the north, and it really isn't gendered in the context the OP described. Men also call men love. That said, tone and context are massively important. While in my hometown, i would not be surprised if a cashier in a supermarket called me love (irrespective of gender), there are contexts where it is used patronisingly. My mum is a working class woman and a feminist and also wouldn't mind because for her, this is a part of working-classness (middle class people in the north don't use these words because the way in which they perform politeness is more distant and less familiar). That said, there are times when she has been offended and its always down to tone. If for example she was making a complaint in a store and someone said 'look love' in a patronising way to undermine her complaint, she would get angry. However, i feel that middle class people and people from less working class areas often fail to read these nuances.

So as another northern working class male, I think you are right in identifying the context in which you used it isn't gendered because men even call other men love (or duck depending on the region) in such settings. Similarly, in South Wales, people call each other beaut. I think these terms of endearment are very much a working class thing and are primarily used in working class post industrial areas with strong histories of community and close social ties rendering what some people consider overfamiliarity just normal polite everyday interaction. I do think a discussion of the nuances of how these words are used is important from an intersection feminist point of view because they are so classed and as you say, not gendered. That said, i think it is important to note that they can still be used in a gendered way. For example, my mum is a working class feminist who has no issue with men or women calling her love, and she calls everyone love herself. However, there have been times when she has been angry at being called love and it has always come down to tone and context. She would have no issue with being called love by a cashier in tesco but if she is making a complaint and someone said 'look love' she would be angry. I feel that when it comes to love being used in a patronising way, it is gendered because men are more likely to use it this way when speaking to women. However, I also think that in this context, love becomes less of a working class thing. I feel that men that would not ordinarily call people love do so when they want to patronise women in such contexts.

Of course not. And for the record, I'm gay. I'm not defending homophobia. My point is that no activists from any group in the past would be worth quoting if we hold them to todays standards. A couple of years ago in the UK there was a women's match celebrating 100 years since the right to vote but not all women could vote. That right did not extend to all women and many suffragettes would have been racist and homophobic. However, it didn't stop people celebrating the movement. It's possible to celebrate the good things that people said and did whilst remaining critical of the bad things. The MLK quote makes and important point that still holds value.

I'm not, as clearly stated, I'm saying that pretty much every social justice movement back then was problematic. That doesn't mean I think it was ok, far from it. However, that doesn't mean that every single thing each movement fought for was bad. We can criticise MLK for his homophobia and misogyny without erasing his positive contribution to the civil rights movement. The civil rights movement, the suffragette movement and the LGBTQ rights movements all had faults, and i have absolutely no issue with those faults being caller out. However, If you are suggesting that people shouldn't listen to anything MLK had to say because he was homophobic, that same sentiment should be extended to all activists of that era who had blind spots to social injustices outside there own. Unfortunately, it seems that people are quick to hold MLK to account and shit all over the good things he achieved way more often than they would say the suffragettes of LGBTQ movement. That double standard is racist IMO. edit: also, while i agree that we should call out historical injustice, that injustice can still be contextualised within a particular social, material and cultural relations. As an SJW in the 21st century, i like to think that i stand up for justice because I'm an inherently good person. I'm not. Just as nobody is born a racist, a homophobe or a misogynist, nobody is born woke. Had i been born 100 years ago, i dare say my outlook would have been very different because i would have grown up in a society with different people and different ideas. Society and culture produces social injustice. We can call out problematic parts of history but i personally feel that this incessant individualising of social injustice is unhelpful because it does nothing to help us understand and change the social, cultural and historical relations that produce things like homophobia. Hell, as a gay man, I would have probably been closeted and homophobic myself back then because it would have been very difficult to find validation and pride growing up in that world. This is not to say everyone would have behaved that way back then. There were of course many people that challenged the system but they were a very small minority, which means the vast majority of woke people now wouldn't have been woke then had they been brought up in that context. Just to repeat, i do not think that makes it ok *at all* but when i judge individuals of that era, that context matters.

Nearly all the trans inclusive feminists I know are post-structuralist. Post structuralism doesn #8217;t mean denying women exist. It is simply about acknowledging that the category woman does not exist as an essential immutable characteristic, and that it is irreducible to any universal single narrative. Intersectional feminism is post-structuralist because it acknowledges the multiple possibilities of what it means to be say a woman in relation to class, race, sexuality, place, age, education etc (and in doing so responds to critiques of earlier structuralist/materialist feminisms that marginalised differences within women. I do think that post-structuralism and queer theory *can* sometimes fall into the trap of making it impossible to define and talk about differences but it doesn #8217;t have to (it all depends on how postmodern it is). However, while a radical postmodern approach to gender falls into the trap of erasing differences and making it difficult to talk about women, a radical modernist approach falls into the trap of universal definitions of womanhood that erases the experiences of women or colour and working class women . When it comes to trans people, it is actually feminists that reject post-structuralism that are exclusionary because their understanding of how oppression works is essentialist and reductive .

You are right. I think a lot can be gained from the ambiguity (I.e. understanding gender oppression as something that is irreducible to assigned to genitals, thinking about how intersections of class and race result in different embodiments of say man, woman or enby). However, it can be taken too far. I think early post-structuralists like Foucault, who has often been referred to as a coset structuralist, and Butler, who is arguably more structuralist than Foucault because of her feminist Lacanian insights, is a far cry away from radical postmodernism. Unfortunately, the way in which such complex theories often end up trickling down overemphasises the ambiguity, fluidity and different possibilities of resisting categorisation and classification (although personally, I feel like this is often a result of people not fully understanding the post-structural or queer theory they are drawing from). I am currently questioning the utility of post-structural theory and queer theory on LGBTQIA politics for my PhD thesis, and I agree that it can be problematic, particularly when it comes to interactions of race and class, which can impose strong material limits on things like sexual fluidity and individual sexual emancipation. Just as earlier structuralist work ignored intersectionality under the guise of universal definitions of #8216;woman #8217; or #8216;gay #8217;, more contemporary post-structuralist thinking can end up individualising things to such an extent that it becomes ahistorical , apolitical and asocial, detached from any structural concerns that impact some groups more than others. However, I reject the idea that post-structuralism is the problem because structuralism also completely ignored certain marginalised groups. For me, it #8217;s about developing theories that respond to the limits of both modernism and postmodernism. I guess it is important for people to consider what they mean by post- . We do not exist outside of structure but we do exceed structure because we are not completely devoid of agency. We can talk about women without reducing woman to something universal because the boundaries of what it means to be a woman are always being negotiated, challenged and pushed (which is not to say that women have agency that exists outside of systemic pressure). Edit: I should mention that I think a big issue with poststructuralism and queer theory is how inaccessible it is. It is only after several years of reading it that I was able to see that it wasn #8217;t completely denying structure but rather trying think beyond structure in roster to theories possibilities of resistance and social change. I think this is why the way these theories trickle down can end up being problematic. People use buzz words like #8216;it #8217;s a social construction #8217; as if social constructions have no bearing on lived reality and we can just embody new one #8217;s at the flip of a coin. I have noticed an overlap between discourse of gender abolitionists and that of people talking about gender through post-structural queer theory. However, I #8217;d say this overlap is more due to people not fully understanding the theory because they have not engaged with how it is applied in sociological/psychological research and have just relied on ideas like #8216;gender and sexuality is fluid #8217;. They are fluid but the process of of change is far far more complex and not always something that can be reduced to individual will

YTA for not seeing a baby as a fully fledged human. I get that you feel uncomfortable around babies because I did too. However, this is something that people have to get over when they have babies in their lives (unless of course they don't care whether the baby grows up to like them). You think that your interactions don't matter because she's just a baby but this is incorrect. In many ways, such early pre-verbal interactions are some of the most important to development. You may not see it but babies are developing a distinct sense of self in relation to those around them. They may not be asserting themselves and relating to the world in a way that you can comprehend but this doesn't mean they are mindless creatures. I had this argument with someone recently, who said babies don't care what adults think. A good example to demonstrate why this is wrong is when a parent leaves a baby to cry rather than constantly giving into the baby's needs. Through this process, a baby starts to recognise itself as something distinct from it's caregiver and adapts it's behaviour in line with what their care giver expects of them. In essence, the baby starts learns to care about what others think in order to get what it wants. I really would recommend trying to get to know you niece because you may be surprised by how fast you get over your discomfort and actually learn to connect with her. It's not about being able to speak to her. Even when a child does start to speak, the way they express themselves can be really weird to those that have no experience with kids so it is still really difficult for a lot of people to even connect with young children. Before my nephew was born, I struggled to interact with all small children because I had no idea what to say to them. However, when you spend more time trying to get past the discomfort of not knowing what to say or how to act, you learn, and as you learn, you see start to see how much these interactions matter because this seemingly mindless creature starts develop a relationship with you which is actually quite specific and different from the relationship it forms with others. I'm going to leave you with this video my sister shared on Facebook last week of a father interacting with his baby. The baby is preverbal but it is very clear from her body language that she has developed a very meaningful relationship with her father. She is not just some stupid baby. Analysing the video from a psychology perspective, this is some A* parenting but actually quite rare precisely because parents often fail to recognise how connected their babies really are to what's going on around them. https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=10156593444281378 amp;id=9335481377

The problem I have with 'it', like others, is that it is tied up with trauma. People are free to reclaim it but as with every word with an oppressive history, I don't think we can expect everyone to reclaim it. Asking me to call someone 'it' feels like asking me to call someone the reword (which has also been reclaimed). I would happily use any other pronoun but I have an issue with it. I know it has been used to describe out sentient being but in the context of speaking about humans, it's been used to objectify and dehumanise people. My grandfather, a holocaust survivor, was referred to as it. I'm sorry but for me, using this word goes far beyond mild discomfort.

Not everyone is ready to reclaim that the word 'it' in the context of human beings. I have relatives that were killed by people that would have referred to them as 'it'. I will never be read to reclaim it.

For me, asking me to call you it is like asking me to call you the f-word. I don't care if people have reclaimed these words in humanising ways, for me, they are deeply dehumanising and tied up with personal trauma so I am not willing to use them. I'd happily call someone purple because as a word, purple does not have an oppressive history. It's rude to expect people to use language that they find traumatic.

I think this is spot on for a great many cases and rings true to those that oppose a range of other social justice causes, although, and i'd be interested to hear what you think, i feel that this kind of defensiveness can be just as common if not more common amongst people that actually care about social justice. In my personal experience, I've encountered a lot of this defensive amongst people who support various progressive causes but don't like to see themselves as oppressors i.e. single issue activists, whether that be feminists, queer activists or class activists, who only focus on their own oppression. I'm a white working class gay man and for a long time, i didn't acknowledge my male privilege or my white privilege because i was so locked into the intersections of my experience that disadvantaged me that i couldn't see how i had any special advantages. The idea that I was contributing to other oppressions when i was fighting against sexual and class oppression took me a long time to recognise. Similarly, I've seen middle class white women downplay their class and race privilege. In fact, a white feminist friend shared a post on Facebook reducing white supremacy to the patriarchy, which, while definitely connected in a great many ways, kind of ignores the role white women play in the reproduction of systems of racism. Another friend who is a woman of colour actually challenged the post on this basis but my friend inititally refused to acknowledge it. She eventually came around but i think she was resistant at first because the idea of contributing to some kinds of oppression as someone heavily involved in fighting against other oppressions was difficult for her to admit. I've experienced something similar around white men being blamed for homophobia. While it's true that white men have historically played a disproportionate role in producing heteronormativity, the actions and attitudes of everyone (including queer people) contribute to it.I guess we don't like to think of ourselves as anything like those we are fighting against.

I think this is the issue with statistics in general. The only way we can get meaningful data on trends that can be extrapolated across entire populations is by isolating variables, which inevitably comes at the cost of erasing the complexity of individuals. However, so long as the limitations are acknowledged, I dont see anything wrong with this. Statistics have a place. As a gay man, I could look at any statistics on men and masculinity and declare them invalid on the basis that it failed to consider any number of intervening variables that mark my experience off as different from that measured in a given study. However, that doesn't mean the statistics are completely useless. As a social scientist myself, i personally prefer to adopt a mixed method approach. I prefer qualitative research methods but quantitative data can be useful. Both have strengths and limitations. Also, when people complain about the limitations of individual academics' work, i feel some understanding should could given to the fact that many of us are on temporary insecure contracts and working up to 40 hours a week teaching, lesson planning and supervising student before we even get chance to do reaearch which has to be conducted, analysed and published within a limited time frame with an ever increasingly diminished budget. There are many structural factors that limit academic freedom, especially when working for universities in poorer countries with less funding. Academics are constantly having to negotiate this and make compromises to be able to do anything, so of course there are limitations. However, i feel the important thing is for academics to be open and honest about those limitations. Finally, i think it is great that the OP came here. Within academia, there is an increasing demand on researchers to involve the public in the design of their projects. This isn't necessarily about getting people to do our homework but rather acknowledging that irrespective of our areas of expertise, we have blind spots and biases result from our lived experience. The best way to address that is not read books but to actually speak to people and groups who are impacted by what we are doing

I mean, i can't argue with what your saying because most of what you are saying are issues i see with quantitative research in general. Like you, i also adopt a participatory approach to research precisely because reducing people to numbers is IMO always a micro-aggression when researching marginalised populations. However, given that this project is specifically on micro-aggressions, i guess it more problematic. I think they definitely need to offer an option for participants to self -id, but even then, i would question the use of quantitative data for a project like this. At the very least, they should include qualitative data to respond to the limitations of using quantitative data.

While this is true for many middle/upper class children with lots of exposure to people speaking proper queens English, it is not true for everyone. Some people need to be taught the rules of the language to counter mistakes they've routinely read/heard. As a working class person, I've had to teach myself grammar. Interestingly, since grammar has been put back on the syllabus, there has been a lot of resistance from middle class leftist parents complaining that kids are being worked too hard by having to learn grammar they never had to learn completely sidelining the fact that not everyone is privileged enough to be surrounded by people always speaking gramatically correct English. I mean, what man? A black man, a gay man, a working class man, a working class black gay man? While we may say men are privileged in certain context, that privilege may shift and change in relation other variables so I dont think it is possible to get such a definitive figure. We can say that certain types of men are more likely to experience privilege but when it comes to individual men, lots of factors may enable or displace that privilege. gt;Studies that have controls, and keep variables constant etc. But studies that do this rely on abstracting variables for measurement which in real life dont exist independently of the countless other variables that are not measured (variables that are constantly changing according to with who, what, where and when we are interacting). IMO there is no such thing as objective reaearch because individuals are far more complex than a handful of categories. However, research can give us an indication of some kind of power imbalance. However, the limitations or statistics mean that we can define privilege in such universal way. I'm a critical realist so I'm interested in casual tendencies that can be measured rather than cause and effect. The former considers how certain variables are *more likely* to lead to certain outcomes but unlike the latter, avoids assuming that those variables cause certain outcomes. Whether or not they do or no is dependent on a whole range of other variables that may come into play

As I said, I dont think we can tell whether one individual is more privileged because if we are looking at individuals, so many other variables come into play. What we can observe are things like whether men are more likely to be accepted into certain fields. That doesn't mean that every man in said field is accepted because of privilege or that every woman is rejected because she is a woman, but if we observe that women in general are less likely to accepted into that field, that is evidence that men *are more likely* as a group to experience an advantage - *more likely* not guaranteed. To put it another way. When I teach my students about economic privilege, they often come back with examples of people from working class backgrounds becoming successful. This is a good example of bow individuals within an oppressed group can still succeed and and access privilege. However, when thinking about working class people as a whole, we know from statistics that those that experience class mobility are the exception and not the rule. As a rule, being working-class makes someone least likely to be economically successful than someone who is middle class. If I was faced with two babies in a hospital ward, with one from a middle class family and one from a working class family, and told I had to bet money on which one would be most economically successful, I would bet on the middle class one because the odds are staked in their favour. Those odds are to some extent measurable, but that doesnt mean the working class person won't end up more successful, it just means that they are less likely to be. Edit: for the record, I am not subscribing to an idea of male privilege that can exist independently of other intervening variables. I am a man from working class background in a very middle class careers. I recently had a middle class woman tell me that it was easier for people like me to get into the field, which I challenged because people from my class background are actually far less likely to even get the necessary qualifications. While I mat have advantages of over working-class women entering my field, I certainly didn't have advantages over the privately education person I was speaking with, so I reject these simplistic notions of privilege. A bit of wider context is necessary when evaluating this stuff because there is no such thing as man versus woman that exists independently of race, class, sexuality etc. The kinds of men and women we are comparing are going to change what we can say about privilege. This is true for any social science research. When different variables come into play, power relations shift. Quantitative research is always limited, which means we can't use it to make absolute judgement about any single individual, but that doesn't mean its useless

Sorry, I was perhaps overly sensitive because I have worked in mental health and I am so used to coming up against misinformation and fear, particularly when it comes to illnesses commonly associated with psych wards I.e. schizophrenia. In most instances, people who are institutionalised are more of a risk to themselves than anyone else. I wasn't sure whether the OP was looking for a date to be honest but if they were, I agree that mental health issues are definitely something to think about before diving into a relationship with someone. Given that this was on a psych ward, I would also question issues around consent. The OP said she went home but I got the impression that the guy stayed on the ward. Here in the UK, that could mean that he has been sectioned, in which case, I don't think he would legally be able to consent to a relationship, which could explain his inability to respect boundaries set by the OP. However, providing both are capable of consent, I don't think dating someone with mental health issues is inherently a bad idea. I think that the question of whether it is good or bad depends on the the issue and how severe It is, but most importantly, how capable and willing the other person is at navigating the extra challenges, not to mention also considering the myriad of other things the person they are dating brings to their relationship. I think a hard set rule on whether people should or shouldn't date someone with mental health issues is ablelist because it goes beyond choosing not to date someone ourselves and projects that on to others. It ignores all the valid reasons why individuals may choose to take on the extra challenges of dating someone with a mental health condition. After all, they are connecting with someone who is more than an illness. I have struggled with partners in the past with mental health difficulties, which was difficult, but I do not regret those relationships. I don't think there is anything wrong with asking people whether they have reflected on the potential implications of dating someone with a mental health problem, for their benefit and the person they're dating, but that is different from telling them not to, which reduces the person they are dating to nothing but a condition. Finally, I also wanted to mention that many on psych wards are there on a one-off basis following traumatic events that they recover from. Some of those that are scared of people in such institutions will end up in one, and many that have come out of them have far better control over their mental health than people in the general population that have issues that are ignored, undiagnosed and untreated. I don't think whether or not someone has been in such an institution is a good measure of how stable they are

I'd argue that while much mainstream porn is objectifying, porn can also be subjectifying. For example, queer scholars such as Mowlabocus and Dyer, and feminist scholars such as Linda Williams, while criticising issues with a lot of porn in terms of forms of objectification that emerge around race and gender, also speak about how porn has offered representation to LGBTQ+ people whose sexualities are desexualised and pathologised in much mainstream media and culture at large. They problematise pro porn advocates for being uncritical about porn representation and consumption but at the same time problematise anti-porn advocates for failing to consider how porn enables and displaces different things for different groups. Gay male porn for instance, while problematic in lots of ways, exceeds the heterosexual male gaze. For many, see such sexualities validate through porn plays enables them to develop sexual agency. Edit: I should have probably mentioned that for lesbian porn, it is more complicated, with queer women often fetishised for a male gaze, although Linda Williams does speak about porn made by and for queer women that disrupts this. There is also some literature on queer women and straight women watching gay male porn because it escapes aspects of the male gaze they are objectified by, and enables them to gaze without feeling they are objectified

I was single, had no kids, and lived in a relatively cheap city, so there were other jobs i could have done. However, i wanted to be self-employed, set my own price for my labour rather than have an employer extract surplus from it, and choose my clients rather have an employer force me to interact with anyone. This thread can't really be about 'simply sex work' because sex for work and consumption does not exist outside of other forms of work and consumption. The decision to sell or consume sex operates within, not outside, consumer capitalism. Sex work doesn't exist in a vacuum. When making a decision of whether sex work in empowering or not, that decision should be considered in relation to the socio-economic system it operates and other forms of work and consumer choices available. The problem I have with anti-sex work narratives, whether focusing on selling or consuming, is that they overlook the voices of actual sex workers 99% of the time, which is kind of ironic considering that the people speaking over sex workers lived experience have no issue using terms like 'mansplaining'. I also feel that it is unfair to discuss sex work independently of other forms of labour because the decision of whether to do it or not does not exist outside of other forms of labour. Separating sex work out from other any other form of labour consumed or produced implies that it is worse than other forms of consumption and production, especially given that the people doing it are investing this discussion into discussing a market that is often already heavily stigmatised and in many places criminalised. I mean, nobody is posting scathing critiques of feminists employing say a cleaner for their house, even though that form of labour exploitation is state sanctioned. Such discussion in my opinion operate to disempower sex workers by removing and stigmatising only \*some\* work and consumer choices.

But isn't evaluating consent within such practices a form of criticism? I'm a submissive gay guy who gets off on stuff like this but when I play with things that might ordinarily be considered violent, I am giving power, not having power taken from me. I feel like this is a massively important distinction. As a sub, I am not actually being dominated because I am only dominated in ways that I choose to be. This is often referred to as the sub paradox. Meanwhile my partner gets off on doing it because I'm aroused. If he was taking power away from me, he wouldn't be aroused, which makes it massively different from a scenario where someone is actually violent. I'm pretty sure my kinks do emerge from problematic power structures. I was bullied a lot in school for being gay and I feel I've sexualised that somehow. However, I was reading a paper recently on the distinction between trauma reenactment and trauma play. Trauma reenactment would involve reliving the past, satisfying my desires with actual abusive people. However, trauma play is about taking the thing which was problematic and using it in a safe space with a partner you can trust. It's about creating a scenario where I am able to play with problematic power dynamics that once hurt me in a way that puts me and my desires in the driving seat. Doing so involves a lot of care and trust. Personally, as a sub, I find that my perfect match is not a sadist who puts their own desires and pleasures above others but rather someone who gets off on being dominant *in response to* my needs. I think people should critically engage with kinks but for me, it's often a question of how they are practiced and with who as opposed to practicing or not.

That's true. I wasn't saying that criticism was wrong. I was saying that talking about dynamics of consent within such scenarios isn't just accepting them with no criticism. Accepting them with no criticism would involve ignoring the nuances of how they are practiced, why, for who, when etc. As someone who is into kinks, I personally don't think television is the right place to broadcast this stuff because it's going to be extremely limited in its ability grapple with the nuances of how such kinks can be practiced safely and respectfully. However, I disagree that such kinks are inherently violent. I've experienced violence with people that have taken power from me, and I've experienced being dominated by people I've given power to. I really do not think that the guys I've played have been capable of actually hurting me

I personally adopt a Foucauldian position on power, popular among post-structural feminists and queer theorists. Foucault saw power as something more complex than something any given person or group has or doesn #8217;t have. His focus was on power relations emerging between people and groups , which is always shifting across time and place. I think this important for being able to account for intersectionality, for example, making sense of the complex power dynamics between a working class black man and an affluent white woman, but I also think it #8217;s important for considering how we are all entangled in (and contribute to) systems of oppression, even when those systems operate against us. This might sound abstract so to ground it in something, take patriarchy for instance. Some understand patriarchy as men exerting power over women. However, post-structuralists see patriarchy as something produced by everyone (to varying degrees), even though it benefits men and historically did emerge through more direct force. For example, women telling boys not to cry and policing other women for failing to live up to certain standards of femininity re-produces patriarchy.

WRITING.TITLE: Is gallows humour always self-deprecating?
WRITING.TEXT: I am currently writing my thesis (social science) and one of the things that has come up is the use of humour as a coping mechanism for dealing with oppression. Sometimes the humour is self deprecating, making light of painful experiences as a coping mechanism. Through reading around this, I #8217;ve come across lots of work on gallows humour and how people how marginalised groups have joked about oppression they have faced as a means of being able to relieve tension and confront things that are otherwise too painful to face. However, some of the humour isn #8217;t self-deprecating. It is punching , punching up to mock oppressive ideas. Would this still fall under gallows humour or is their another concept for this type of humour ?

WRITING.TITLE: Do notions of patriarchal bargain fairly account for privilege and power gained in excess of patriarchy?
WRITING.TEXT: My title is a little abstract so let me explain, but before I do, I just want to acknowledge that my thoughts on this are a little scattered and I #8217;m struggling to articulate them so if this all just complete rubbish, inconsistent or based on misunderstanding, I #8217;m totally open to criticism. As an active contributor to this community, I am here in good faith. This is not an attack on feminism but something I #8217;ve observed across multiple social justice movements in which I #8217;m either an ally or active participant. I often see bad things women do that affect other marginalised groups reduced to patriarchy. I may be misunderstanding the idea of the patriarchal bargain but the way I #8217;ve interpreted it is that women sometimes assimilate with patriarchal expectations to access power otherwise denied to them. The issue I have with this is that sometimes the power accessed is power over other marginalised groups. A lot of working class and black feminist scholars have spoke about how white middle class femininities have been weaponised against other groups, so I #8217;m wondering if it #8217;s always fair to reduce assimilation with a white bourgeois masculinist system to nothing but a struggle against power when what is gained through such bargains is also often power over marginalised groups. I should mention that I see the same thing with other social justice movements. I #8217;m queer and often see queer people assimilating with racist and classist systems similarly reduced to victims. For example, LGBTQ supporters for trump are often reduced to self-haters desperate to gain respectability and status within a system that works against them. Similarly, I think that this ignores the many reasons an LGBTQ person might vote for conservative groups and assimilate with conservative people #8217;s expectations beyond self-hate and pressure from heteronormativity. For example, I #8217;m sure that many white affluent LGBTQ republicans know that the party does not represent their interests but make an active choice to support them in order to sustain say their economic interests and white privilege. What could be considered a heteronormative bargain could be less about wanting to be respected by straight/cis people and more about be willing take their losses under heteronormativity in order benefit and exert power over other marginalised groups.

No worries. There is a really good book on the gay history of New York that goes into detail about the Kinsey study and subsequent counter studies that have failed to replicate the results. It is by someone called Chauncey. I may have a copy I can link you to on Dropbox if you #8217;re interested. Essentially, what the more contemporary literature has shown is that most people are straight (in terms of both identity and behaviour) but people in between are far more common than those that are exclusively gay/lesbian. I am a sociologist that specialises in sexuality so I am familiar with a lot of literature *but* my knowledge is heavily restricted to interview and survey data. I do believe some of this stuff has been replicated by studies measuring subconscious arousal patterns but that work falls outside my area of expertise. If I remember rightly, studies on arousal patterns have shown that more people fall in between than suggested by self-reported data but the majority are still straight (this is definitely true for men although I have a feeling it may not be the case for women. I #8217;d have to revisit the literature to check). That said, i do know that the measures of those arousal studies have also been criticised. However, your assertion that sexuality is a spectrum is 100% correct, and I think it #8217;s worth noting that these studies only show us the distribution of sexualities at a particular time. There is plenty of evidence to suggest that sexuality could be more fluid than it presently is if it wasn #8217;t for the cisheteronormative culture we grow up in. As sociologists, we often show this by pointing to the rich variation of sexuality across time and different cultures. This stuff is always changing so it is possible that in the future, everyone could fall in the middle. Chauncey actually makes an interesting argument against the counter studies not based on their validity at the time they were conducted but on the basis that sexuality was understood and embodied differently at the time Kinsey wrote. One of the things he mentions, which fits with what you are saying about gender being a spectrum, Is that at the time Kinsey wrote, many people, particularly working-class and non-white populations, had grown up in cultures where sexuality was understood and organised more around gender presentation than sex. For example, he talks about how during the 18th and 19th century, it was common for feminine men to be considered as being like women, so a man sleeping with a man wouldn #8217;t have necessarily been understood as gay or even bi. Edit: the way gender and sexuality used to be understood and embodied is exemplified quite nicely by the etymology of the word molly, which , at the time Chauncey is referring to, was used synonymously for male sodomites, effeminate men, female sex workers and working class women. Edit 2: when I say sexuality could be more fluid if it wasn #8217;t for the cisheteronormative culture we grow up in, i just want to be clear that I #8217;m not suggesting that sexual orientation is something that can be changed at will. Hopefully this is clear but happy to unpack this more if not

WRITING.TITLE: Is it ok to assume gender to call out privilege?
WRITING.TEXT: Hey everyone, so I #8217;m a sociologist and was having a discussion recently with a colleague who was carrying out some covert qualitative observational work but didn #8217;t speak about gender dynamics because he didn #8217;t want to assume the genders of the people he was made observing. I was just wondering what people thought about this. For example, if I think back through my own experience, I can recount countless scenarios where I have been in seminars or at conferences where men speak over women. In many of these instances, I don #8217;t 100% know if they were all actually men because I didn #8217;t get to know them one to one, It #8217;s definitely possible that some of them may have identified differently. However, I still feel that speaking of those gender dynamics, despite some degree of uncertainty , is important. However, I #8217;m definitely open to being challenged on this and I would love to hear everyone else #8217;s thoughts.
Thanks for sharing. This is a really helpful :-)

Thanks. This is also very helpful. I have also done research involving gender but this has never come up as a an issue because my research isn #8217;t covert. The issue my colleague had was observing people covertly in public spaces so there was no opportunity for the people he observed to be self-id.

Yes, I agree. I guess my point was that nobody is ever clearly anything. Some AFAB enby people I know are very feminine and are often get read as women even though they are not. In usual circumstances, I would just focus on the behaviour tbf but in the case in the question , my friend was doing research, and without asking each person what their gender is (which he couldn #8217;t because it was a covert study) , he could not talk about gender power dynamics in the group he observed

That #8217;s fair. So if I was at say a conference, it wouldn #8217;t be fair to say the men were often taking over the conversation and mansplaining unless I specifically know they self ID as male ? That was my friends position

Yes, this exactly what I thought. It #8217;s like when people call out people for mansplaining online or assume someone is cishet for saying something homophobic or transphobic . We often see people respond with things like #8216;are you assuming my gender #8217; but I feel that when they are behaving in ways typically male/cishet and problematic, those assumptions are understandable.
Yes, that works. Thanks :-)

Tbh, it #8217;s not really my area. My work, and all the work I cite, is overt, mostly because from an ethical standpoint, covert work can only really be justified if studying something where there is a justifiable reason why you don #8217;t want the people you observe to know they are being observed. The study in question that led me to ask this question was that of a colleague in a different area. However, if it #8217;s something you are interested in, google covert ethnography. I think it #8217;s more common in criminology than sociology

Thanks. I totally agree. I also share your critique of the limitations of covert research. As I said, this is a colleague #8217;s study. I personally use participatory methods which are very unstructured in order to allow the participants to structure the direction of research.

Yes, I unpacked this more in one of the other comments but essentially, i think It is legal providing the study is conducted in a public place. However, legal doesn #8217;t mean ethical so in order to get a covert study past an ethics board, the researcher would have to defend their case. Even if legal, there would have to be some major benefits to not informing people to gain ethical approval. Unfortunately, that is all I can tell you. I do not know so much about it because I have never done such studies. The post was in regard to a colleague #8217;s study. My work is never covert. As such, I do always ask for gender. However, if it #8217;s something you want to know more about, I #8217;d recommend googling covert ethnography. Edit: just asked a friend and apparently there can be legal issues to covert research so don #8217;t take my word on the public thing. It #8217;s probably more complicated. Part of applying for ethics would involve navigating any legal issues but . I #8217;m not 100% sure of the details. My friend also told me that ethics would only be approved in cases where there are no alternatives and the participants being aware of the project would significantly alter the results . https://study.cardiffmet.ac.uk/AcSkills/Documents/Research/Research_Ethics_elesson/page_14.htm

Thanks for sharing. I #8217;m not disagreeing with you on the ethics issues. As I said, I am not the one conducting a covert study here. I #8217;m guessing legality must vary by place and field because I know that they can be conducted in some instances in the UK. They are rare and very hard to get past ethics but they are not always illegal. I mean, journalists record and make observations of people in public all the time. Edit: i think it #8217;s also worth noting that a lot of research uses data made publicly available online, which can in many instances be used for research and journalism. In these instances, individual consent would not always be given but gender dynamics of a particular online platform may still be discussed Edit 2: *The palgrave handbook of ethics in critical research* includes a section of covert research, which includes recent studies . I said the world is not California because of your assumption that I was conflating two groups based on your situated experience of those two groups in California. I #8217;m not in California. I have to disagree. Class exploitation and inherited wealth built on the back of it marks a form of structural inequality. It is not just a personal issue. I am a gay man but I have been far more limited by class inequality than homophobia (obviously this will vary from place to place). I agree that it is not the same as homophobia and racism, but it is still a systemic issue, rooted in a history that is still made present. White working class people, while historically not denied the right to self-determination anywhere near as much as BIPOC, have still been exploited and restricted throughout history in ways that middle class people haven #8217;t. However, I would agree that racism carries much more baggage because of slavery and colonialism - the worst kind of class exploitation contributing to far more inherited wealth. I am not trying to pit class against race because class exploitation actually harms BIPOC more than white people. Building on Kage-e #8217;s comment, I would also recommend the work of Sarah Ahmed, who draws on Freud, and Braidotti, who draws on Irigaray. As already mentioned, these theorists oppose psychoanalysis as normalising science instead using it make sense of internal struggles in ways that remain open to fluidity and difference. Walkerdine #8217;s and Jimenez #8217;s book *Gender, work and community* is also a really good one to see Deleuze and Guattari put to use with psychoanalysis. Again, they maintain an open commitment to recognising transformative possibilities of difference beyond binaries while also accounting for affective/emotional constraints. There is also a journal article that looks at the work of the psychoanalyst Melanie Klein alongside Deleuze and Guattari. I can #8217;t remember what it is called atm but I #8217;ll try to dig it out. From reading that, it seems fair to say that anti-Oedipus is not anti-psychoanalysis but anti-oedpialisation (I.e. anti normalisation). Deleuze and Guattari depart from Klein #8217;s notion of the depressive position (I.e. the position at which the subject is held to become contained). However, their szchizoanalysis in many ways resonates with Klein #8217;s paranoid-schizoid position (held as an earlier state of development), which for Deleuze and Guattari is never made whole or complete by linear notions of development). I hope this make sense but let me know if you need further clarification. I would also recommend posting this question to the asksocialscience reddit.

To be honest, the Klein bit is the bit I know the least about. Everything I have is from that journal article. I #8217;ll dig it out for you this eve and send it over :-). I guess the main connection is that the subject (or non subject) of Deleuze and Guattari is kind of like the pre-Oedipal Kleinian subject, always yet to be and become other as opposed to organised. Like many analysts, Klein #8217;s theory privileged linear developmental narratives. I guess Deleuze and Guattari depart from her in that they theorise #8216;development #8217; as messy and non-linear, if that makes sense. The object relations of Klein never find order, and certainly can #8217;t be reduced to binary narratives. One thing I found useful for understanding Deleuze and Guattari in relation to psychoanalysis was how they use Nietzschean philosophy. Both Freud and Deleuze and Guattari draw on Nietzsche. For Freud, Nietzsche #8217;s will to power was essentially the polymorphously perverse Id, which through oedipalisation develops an ego structured by the superego. For Deleuze and Guattari, we could say that the polymorphously perverse Id is never fully contained , it that makes sense. The will to power, rather than being structured, is productive, disrupting existing structures and marking out new directions for being and becoming. Even though we are still constrained in various ways, the way in which that constraint plays out is irreducible you fixed narratives. Foucualt #8217;s will to knowledge-power set out along a similar path, considering how power is always contested between bodies as opposed to say Freud that saw power as an outside force. Anyway, I hope this helps. I #8217;ll dig out that article for you later Edit: I also like to the think of these post-Oedipal theories as re-defining things like narcissism and hysteria, psychopathologised by the likes of Freud as a primitive state in opposition to civilisation, as as positive productive force. After all , that which was positioned as narcissistic and primitive was essentially anything that failed to align with the white bourgeois phallocentic order. It is from that excess that we have been able to question the primitive/civilised binary, opening up space for difference. In this sense, the id becomes a site of resistance affording possibilities of social change.
